item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈ´òÁ∫øÂÖ¨Âõ≠ÁöÑÈò¥ËåéÁ≤âÁ∫¢Ëâ≤ÈõïÂ°ëÂñ∑Ê∞¥ÔºåËÆ©Ê∏∏ÂÆ¢Â†ïËêΩÔºö ‚Äú‰∏çË¶ÅÂú®ÂÆÉÂâçÈù¢ÊëÜÂßøÂäø‚Äù | Phallic pink sculpture at NYC High Line squirts water, drenches tourists in depravity: ‚ÄòWon‚Äôt be posing in front of it‚Äô
item.description:
The High Line is footing its own Viagra Falls.

A very phallic, very pink foot sculpture fountain has aroused curiosity and disgust alike as it suggestively sprays water on passersby at the famous Manhattan elevated park.

‚ÄúI like that you can turn the water on ‚Äî but ehh, I won‚Äôt be posing in front of it. Nope.‚Äù said Brooklynite visitor Danny L., 40.

The 10-foot tall sculpture titled ‚ÄúFoot Fountain (pink)‚Äù by Argentine-born artist Mika Rottenberg was erected in April along the High Line near 30th Street.

The public art installation shaped like a pink foot and, um, leg ‚Äî which is dotted with lurid red-lipped mouths sticking out tongues ‚Äî quickly drew hard looks from dirty-minded New Yorkers and tourists.

‚ÄúSo just so we‚Äôre clear‚Äî nobody saw a foot,‚Äù one Instagram commenter insinuated.

Another commenter got explicit: ‚ÄúI clearly saw a pink penis.‚Äù

Beyond the sculpture‚Äôs titillating silhouette, there‚Äôs also how passersby can lend it a hand.

The artwork has a cycle across the path that encourages High Line pedestrians to pedal, using their foot power to activate a fountain at the top of its shaft ‚Äî a feature that could get unsuspecting viewers wet if prematurely activated.

Sanjeet Singh, a 46-year-old tourist from India, called the sculpture ‚Äúodd.‚Äù

‚ÄúInteresting, but I promise you, you will only see these kinds of things in America,‚Äù Singh said.

‚ÄúIn my country, this would be consider too much,‚Äù though Singh appreciatively added, ‚ÄúIt is funny-looking though.‚Äù

Several Instagram users opined the scabrous sculpture perhaps inadvertently made a firm case for raising awareness of sexually transmitted infections, with one calling it ‚Äúherpetic.‚Äù

Danny R., 29, who was visiting from San Francisco, called the sculpture ‚Äúuncomfortable,‚Äù even though she was a fan overall.

‚ÄúIt gives some kind of itchy because of the holes and stuff coming out of it,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs disturbing. But it‚Äôs cool, really cool.‚Äù

Others on the High Line viewed it more innocently.

Upper West Side mom Angie R., 35, was delighted to come across the ‚Äúfunky‚Äù artwork while walking with her three kids Monday.

‚ÄúThe kids love it because it‚Äôs really just a tall sprinkler,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúSo they can run around it while one of them is using the bike.‚Äù

Italian tourist Katie Sareno, 27, also praised it for being fun and kid-friendly.

‚ÄúFun for kids, but you know the adults will see the real art,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúKudos to the artist.‚Äù

Rottenberg didn‚Äôt return a request for comment.

‚ÄúFoot Fountain (pink)‚Äù will be on display until May 2026.
item.author: Desheania Andrews, Matt Troutman

item.title: Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÁΩëÁ∫¢Âú®Â∏¶ÁùÄÂ•π7Â≤ÅÁöÑÂ•≥ÂÑøÂñ∑ÊôíÊôíÈªëÂêéÁåõÁÉàÊä®ÂáªÔºö ‚ÄúÊàë‰ª¨‰∏çÂÜçËØ¥‰∏ç‰∫ÜÂêóÔºü‚Äù | NJ influencer slammed after taking her 7-year-old daughter to spray tan: ‚ÄòDo we not say no anymore?‚Äô
item.description:
New Jersey-dwelling momfluencer Noel LaPalomento is no stranger to mother-daughter makeover sessions ‚Äî face masks, nail salons, and try-on hauls seem to be staples in the family‚Äôs household.

The glam Garden Stater has racked up a following of 2.6M users on her TikTok account, @_the1stnoel, and frequently posts content featuring her 7-year-old, Giada.

In fact, almost all of her top-performing videos, with tens of millions of views each, see the 28-year-old styling her sidekick‚Äôs hair in a series that has become beloved by LaPalomento‚Äôs followers.

The diva-esque duo‚Äôs latest adventure? A trip to the tanning salon ‚Äî¬†and some followers weren‚Äôt along for the ride.

The comment section commotion kicked off after LaPalomento posted a TikTok joking about Giada asking to join her mom for a spray tan.

As influencers tend to do, the TikTokker showed off the session, posting a second video detailing the salon experience, followed by a final post dedicated to the much-anticipated results.

LaPalomento clarified in the video series that the spray tan ingredients were ‚Äújust sugar and water,‚Äù and that Giada‚Äôs aunt was the spray tan artist who was featured in the video, but unsurprisingly, the Internet was irate over the light-hearted videos.

‚ÄúDo we not say no anymore?‚Äù quipped a disapproving viewer.

Though this particular comment racked up over 50,000 likes, it also prompted several replies defending the momfluencer.

‚ÄúDo we not mind our own business anymore?‚Äù retorted one user, while another responded: ‚ÄúWhy would she? It‚Äôs not like anyone is going to get hurt,‚Äù referring to the natural ingredients in the tanning solution and family supervision.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt even know what a spray tan was at 7‚Ä¶‚Äù said another shocked commenter.

Many critics expressed concern about the 7-year-old‚Äôs sense of self-esteem and health as a result of exposure to makeup and beauty treatments, but LaPalomento was quick to address this backlash in a separate video.

‚ÄúI just feel like it sets a certain beauty standard at a young age,‚Äù worried a viewer.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt agree,‚Äù the momfluencer replied. ‚ÄúShe knows makeup, nails, etc, is just for fun and a way to express yourself and be creative.‚Äù

Other mothers sounded off in the comments of the original series and shared similar opinions.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather get my kid a spray tan than have them lie out in the sun. She looks so cute!‚Äù said one reply, while another reminisced: ‚ÄúMy mom and I always did what we called Paris Hilton day once a month: spray tan, nails, shopping, lunch.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour parenting style is exactly who I aspire to be as a mother!!!!‚Äù gushed a fan. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so refreshing seeing you let her live her best life and be herself and experience girlhood love you for that.‚Äù

Meanwhile, dozens of users took to the comments just looking for the location of the tanning salon.

‚ÄúThat is the most perfect looking spray tan I‚Äôve ever seen,‚Äù replied one covetous commenter.

Though LaPalomento‚Äôs decision caught plenty of flak from haters, her no-judgment approach to letting her daughter explore different methods of self-expression also won her support from viewers ‚Äî many of whom left replies mocking critics.

‚ÄúThis is actually so dangerous because she might grow up to be a baddie who loves experiencing things with her mom,‚Äù said one sardonic commenter, while another wrote: ‚ÄúThis is so WRONG!!!!! Simply because I didn‚Äôt get to join this iconic girls‚Äô day.‚Äù

Others simply emphasized the role that artificial tanning plays in Jersey culture.

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt realize we‚Äôre just from New Jersey,‚Äù affirmed a fellow Garden State native, while another astute NJer said: ‚ÄúOnce I heard the accents I was like, ‚ÄòOh okay she‚Äôs in the hands of a professional.'‚Äù

The professionals in question ‚Äî Glow Lab in Sewell, NJ ‚Äî use spray tanning tech that is naturally derived, and doesn‚Äôt contain parabens, gluten, sulfates, mineral oils, or nut oils, making it a much safer alternative to the beds that took over tanning culture in the 2000s.

The Post has reached out to LaPalomento for comment.
item.author: Caroline Cubbin

item.title: Â´åÁñë‰∫∫Ë¢´ÊéßÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈ™ÑÂÇ≤Ê∏∏Ë°åÊúüÈó¥ÂºïÂèëÂ§ßËßÑÊ®°Ë∏©Ë∏è‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÁÜäÂñ∑ÈõæË¢≠ÂáªÔºö ‚ÄúÂÖ®Ë∫´ÂëïÂêê‚Äù | Suspect charged for bear spray attack that sparked massive stampede during NYC Pride: ‚ÄòVomiting all over‚Äô
item.description:
A 23-year-old New Yorker was nabbed for allegedly unleashing bear spray at a massive crowd of Pride revelers inside Washington Square Park, apparently out of fear of being assaulted himself, cops and sources said.¬†

Dominick Sabater, 23, of Harlem, allegedly sprayed the substance ‚Äì held inside an 8.1 ounce container with an image of a bear on the label ‚Äì as the crowd in the greenspace swelled to about 1,000 people around 7:50 p.m., authorities and law enforcement sources said.¬†

‚ÄúAt some point, a determination was made not to let anybody else into the park. It was overcrowded,‚Äù Chief of Detectives Joseph Kenny told reporters Monday. ‚ÄúThey were using gates to let people leave the park, but nobody was allowed in. At some point, officers are made aware of a disturbance. It appears like a fight is going on.‚Äù

Sabater allegedly used the potent substance as a ‚Äúdeterrent‚Äù to keep the crowd away from him, out of fear that he would be jumped or get involved in a fight, the sources said.¬†

Forty-seven members of the crowd were treated by EMS at the scene, and four others were taken to Bellevue Hospital, where they were listed in stable condition, cops said.¬†

It wasn‚Äôt immediately clear how many injuries were due to the repellant, and how many were sustained during the ensuing stampede, but none were expected to be life-threatening.

Additionally, a dozen police officers who were exposed to the spray were also taken to Northwell Greenwich Village Hospital for treatment, police said.¬†

‚ÄúOfficers rushed to the scene, and they are immediately hit with an orange substance that causes them irritation to their eyes, and some of them actually couldn‚Äôt breathe,‚Äù Kenny said. ‚ÄúSo this resulted in 12 officers being removed to the hospital where they were treated for various injuries to their eyes, their throats, into their lungs, difficulty breathing.‚Äù

A photographer caught up in the mace attack told The Post that ‚Äúpeople were vomiting all over,‚Äù adding that it looked like a cop got hit ‚Äúpretty hard‚Äù with the spray.‚Äù

Another shutterbug said the spray was scary, ‚Äúbecause I didn‚Äôt know what it was,‚Äù adding that ‚Äúpeople were having asthma attacks.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy mind went chemical attack,‚Äù he said.

Sabater was arrested at the scene and charged with assault, reckless endangerment, obstruction of governmental administration, menacing, criminal possession of a weapon and unlawful possession of a noxious material, police said.¬†His arraignment was pending Monday afternoon.

He has one prior arrest for an assault on Oct.19, 2021, in which he allegedly reached through a driver‚Äôs window and bashed him in the right eye with a cellphone on East 14th Street near Third Avenue, cops said.¬†

Sabater appeared to be a stranger to the victim, and the attack appeared unprovoked.¬†

The circumstances around his release were not immediately clear.¬†

The mayhem surrounding the Pride festivities continued more than two hours later, where an innocent 17-year-old girl was hurt in a burst of gunfire that left another teen clinging to life just steps from the historic Stonewall Inn where revelers gathered after the Big Apple‚Äôs Pride Parade.

A third teen girl was also slashed in the mayhem, cops said.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: Ex-Hochul Ôºå CuomoÂä©ÊâãË¢´ÊåáÊéß‰∏∫‰∏≠ÂõΩÈó¥Ë∞çÔºåÂú®ËÅîÈÇ¶Ë∞ÉÊü•Â±ÄÊé®Âá∫800‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉ‰∏™‰∫∫Èò≤Êä§Ë£ÖÂ§áÂõûÊâ£ËÆ°ÂàíÁöÑÊñ∞ÊåáÊéßÊó∂Ôºå‰ªçÂèØÂÖçË¥πÂÖ•‰Ωè | Ex-Hochul, Cuomo aide accused of being Chinese spy stays free as feds push new charges in $8M PPE kickback scheme
item.description:
There‚Äôs something new under the sun.

Linda Sun, the embattled ex-aide to Govs. Kathy Hochul and Andrew Cuomo accused of being a Chinese spy, will stay free on bail after facing a federal judge Monday on fresh bribery charges.

Sun and her husband Chris Hu both pleaded not guilty during a four-minute proceeding in Brooklyn that set the stage for a potentially sprawling trial focused on accusations she served as a foreign agent for the People‚Äôs Republic of China and Chinese Community Party while working at the highest level of New York‚Äôs government.

A federal grand jury last week returned a superseding indictment that added more charges against Sun and Hu after the feds said they reaped $8 million in a COVID-era personal protective equipment kickback scheme.

‚ÄúNot only did Sun allegedly use Chinese money and her influence in New York State to benefit the Chinese government, it is further alleged that she used her position to steer multi-million-dollar contracts to companies controlled by family members and friends,‚Äù said Harry T. Chavis, Jr., special agent in charge for the Internal Revenue Service‚Äôs criminal investigation office in New York.

The two Chinese-based PPE vendors that Sun steered contracts toward were respectively run by her second cousin and Hu and his business partner, the feds alleged.

Sun allegedly even altered an email to claim one company had been recommended by a China-based chamber of commerce, when it actually was run by her second cousin, prosecutors said.

The cousin had allegedly given $2.3 million in kickbacks to Sun and Hu, the feds contended.

A judge kept Sun‚Äôs and Hu‚Äôs respective $1.5 million and $500,000 bonds ‚Äî which they posted after they were first charged in September with acting as foreign agents for China ‚Äî intact, meaning they‚Äôll remain out of federal jail until trial.

Sun, 41, who wore a blue dress, entered a not guilty plea alongside Hu, 40, during the latest arraignment.

Their trial is scheduled to begin Nov. 3 ‚Äî a day before New York City‚Äôs mayoral election in which Sun‚Äôs former boss Andrew Cuomo remains on the ballot as an independent, despite being drubbed by socialist Zohran Mamdani in the Democratic primary.

Sun also worked for the governor‚Äôs office under Kathy Hochul until 2023, when she was fired after misconduct accusations surfaced.

‚ÄúThis individual was hired by the Executive Chamber more than 10 years ago. Her employment was terminated in March 2023 after discovering evidence of misconduct, her actions were immediately reported to law enforcement and we have assisted law enforcement throughout this process,‚Äù a spokesperson for Hochul said in a statement.
item.author: Kyle Schnitzer, Matt Troutman

item.title: ÈöèÁùÄMTAÊ¥æÂá∫‚ÄúÂ§ß‰Ωø‚Äù„ÄÅÈ¶ñÂ∏≠ÊâßË°åÂÆòË≠¶Âëä‰πòÂÆ¢ÂèëÁîüÂèòÂåñÔºåÁöáÂêéÂå∫Â∑¥Â£´Ë∑ØÁ∫øÂá∫Áé∞Â∑®Â§ßÂä®Ëç° | Queens bus routes see huge upheaval as MTA sends ‚Äòambassadors,‚Äô CEO to warn riders of changes
item.description:
The MTA launched a major overhaul of the Queens bus system ‚Äî with trained ‚Äúambassadors‚Äù deployed into the community to warn riders of the upheaval.

MTA CEO Janno Lieber showed up to join the ambassadors to speak to community members Monday ‚Äî one day after the launch of the redesign, which includes 16 new routes, 67 changed routes and five discontinued routes.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre spending $35 million more a year to give Queens better, faster bus service,‚Äù Lieber said at a press conference outside the Main St/Kissena Blvd Q20 bus stop. ‚ÄúThese are real benefits for people in Queens. This is what good government looks like.‚Äù

The changes are the first phase of the long-awaited Queens Bus Network Redesign project, which is the most recent change to the borough‚Äôs bus routes since the 1950s.

The changes include rush routes that have been added to quickly bring passengers from underserved areas to transit hubs, such as Jamaica and Flushing, officials announced

For example, one route, the Q13, will be designed to shuttle passengers between Bell Boulevard in Bayside and Flushing, Chris Pangilinan, the MTA‚Äôs ‚ÄúBus Boss,‚Äù explained to reporters and commuters.

The ambassadors ‚Äî numbering in the hundreds ‚Äî are tasked with informing the roughly 800,000 commuters affected by the new route changes, Lieber said.

Still, language barriers and the long-time rituals of some commuters made residents uneasy about the new changes.

While handing out pamphlets to explain the changes in service on the Q20 to bus passengers, Lieber was met with confused looks from passengers who did not speak English, The Post observed.

They were later reassured by a 27-year-old MTA worker, Charlie Zhen, who is fluent in both Mandarin and Cantonese and could explain the route changes.

Pamphlets were also translated into Chinese to increase their readability for some passengers.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good. It‚Äôs better for me. I knew. The signs in my language,‚Äù said 67-year-old Flushing resident Xi Jin.

Omar, 22, said he was glad he wasn‚Äôt affected directly by the changes, as he was heading to his job as a security guard in the Bronx on the Q44.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good thing for me, nothing changed. I don‚Äôt need any more aggravation. You got the heat, the humidity, the crowds just to go to work‚Ä¶ going to work is aggravating enough,‚Äù he said.

The second phase of the redesign will be implemented on Aug. 31, officials said.
item.author: Kevin Sheehan, Zoe Hussain

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÊïôÂ∏àÂ∑•‰ºöËÄÅÊùøËøàÂÖã¬∑È©¨Â∞îÊ†ºÈ≤ÅÔºà Mike Mulgrew ÔºâÂú®‚ÄúÊ∏ÖÊ¥ó‚Äù‰∏≠‰ªéUTFÂ∑•ËµÑÂçï‰∏≠È©±ÈÄêÁ´û‰∫âÂØπÊâãÂíåÊâπËØÑËÄÖ | NYC teachers‚Äô union boss Mike Mulgrew ousts rivals, critics from UTF payroll in ‚Äòpurge‚Äô
item.description:
City teachers union President Mike Mulgrew has launched a ‚Äúpurge‚Äô‚Äô at UFT headquarters ‚Äî firing open rivals and also staffers even suspected of being critical of him, sources said.

Amy Arundell, a longtime United Federation of Teachers staffer and former Mulgrew ally who recently challenged him for the presidency and lost, was one of five union activists who recently got the boot.

Arundell told The Post she was informed late last week that she was off the payroll effective Aug. 31, while the UFT immediately disabled her union email and phone.

‚ÄúI consider it a purge,‚Äù siad Arundell, 56, a city Department of Education teacher for 34 years and a paid union staffer for 21 years.

‚ÄúMulgrew is a very spiteful man.‚Äù

While Arundell anticipated she might get the ax for challenging Mulgrew in the recent union election, she was shocked that others were removed from the union payroll as well.

‚ÄúHe should manage the union with union values,‚Äù said Arundell ‚Äî who filed a police report earlier this month after her image and the message, ‚ÄúPiss on My Face‚Äù were put on laminated cards that were then placed in urinals at the UFT‚Äôs Broadway headquarters during a delegate assembly meeting.

Meanwhile, Migda Rodriguez, vice chairwoman of the union‚Äôs chapter representing paraprofessionals, also lost her salaried position.

She had run for an executive position on Arundell‚Äôs A Better Contract slate but lost.

Rodriguez still represents the paraprofessionals and slammed Mulgrew and his ‚ÄúUnity Caucus‚Äù for her ouster.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs retaliation to the fullest. It‚Äôs wrong,‚Äù Rodriguez said.

She said her combined Department of Education and union salary is $80,000 and that it will likely now be halved.

Under the union contract, teachers and other educators get ‚Äúleave time‚Äù from their school jobs to work for the union.

Arundell, Rodriguez and others will get reassigned to a school after losing their paid union staff job.

The union group Fix Para Pay issued a statement condemning Rodriguez‚Äôs termination.

‚ÄúMigda wasn‚Äôt fired for doing anything wrong. She was fired for doing everything right, for advocating fiercely for paras, for demanding a living wage, and for refusing to play politics with our livelihoods,‚Äù the group said.

‚ÄúShe is now part of the `UFT 5‚Ä≤, a group of educators and unionists terminated for choosing principle over party. ‚Ä¶ This move is not only disrespectful to Migda, it may be a direct violation of the UFT constitution and a slap in the face to every member who believes in a democratic union.‚Äù

Ashley Rzonca, the union‚Äôs District 30 representative in Queens, also confirmed she got the boot.

She had sent a letter to her supervisor complaining about ‚Äúbullying and harassing behavior‚Äù from a fellow employee in the UFT ‚Äòs Queens Borough Office, where she worked.

Every morning, the NY POSTcast offers a deep dive into the headlines with the Post‚Äôs signature mix of politics, business, pop culture, true crime and everything in between. Subscribe here!

Rzonca said she did not oppose Mulgrew‚Äôs re-election, but there was concern that some of the 42 school union chapter leaders she oversaw did.

She claimed no major issues were raised about her job performance.

Mulgrew, responding to The Post through a union rep, declined to discuss the reasons for the dismissals.

‚ÄúWe do not comment on individual personnel decisions. As part of its annual organizational assessment, the UFT reviews the status of individuals who are on leave from their schools to work at the union,‚Äù the representative said.

‚ÄúThose whose leaves [leave time to work for the union] are not renewed are thanked for their service and can return to their regular school assignment.‚Äù
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: Sean ‚ÄòDiddy‚Äò CombsÂÆ°Âà§ÁöÑÂÆ°ËÆÆÈô∑ÂÖ•Âõ∞Â¢ÉÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫‰∏ÄÂêçÈô™ÂÆ°ÂëòÊòæÁÑ∂Êó†Ê≥ïÈÅµÂæ™Ê≥ïÂÆòÁöÑÊåáÁ§∫ | Deliberations in Sean ‚ÄòDiddy‚Äô Combs‚Äô trial hit snag as one juror apparently can‚Äôt follow judge‚Äôs instructions
item.description:
Sean ‚ÄúDiddy‚Äù Combs‚Äô bombshell sex-trafficking trial hit a snag Monday just an hour after jury deliberations started ‚Äî because one juror apparently couldn‚Äôt follow the judge‚Äôs instructions.

The panel sent a note to Manhattan federal Judge Arun Subramanian at around 12:40 p.m. expressing concerns about one of the jurors.

‚ÄúWe have a juror, ‚ÄòJuror 25,‚Äô who we believe cannot follow your instructions,‚Äù the note said.

The juror in question has a heavy European accent.

Subramanian said he would send a note back to the jury telling them to keep deliberating.

The panel was sent to the jury room at around 11:30 a.m. to start weighing the charges against Combs, who has pleaded not guilty.
item.author: Ben Kochman, Priscilla DeGregory

item.title: ÁñØÂ≠êÂú®Êó†Á´ØÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇË¢≠Âáª‰∏≠Ëá¥ÂëΩÂú∞Âà∫‰º§‰∫ÜÂøÉÁà±ÁöÑFDNYÈòüÈïøÔºå‰∫ÜËß£‰∫Ü‰ªñÁöÑÂëΩËøê | Maniac who fatally stabbed beloved FDNY captain in unprovoked NYC attack learns his fate
item.description:
The maniac who fatally stabbed a beloved FDNY paramedic in an unprovoked attack got the max prison sentence Monday ‚Äî as dozens of EMS workers packed the Queens courtroom.

Peter Zisopoulos, 37, who was found guilty of second-degree murder last month in the senseless 2022 killing of veteran and 9/11 hero FDNY Capt. Alison Russo, looked bored at the hearing ‚Äî until the judge gave him a massive wake-up call, slapping him with 25 years to life behind bars.

‚ÄúThank God,‚Äù the slain EMT‚Äôs daughter, Danielle Russo, told reporters afterward.

‚ÄúI just hope she can see what we are doing, what‚Äôs being done for her,‚Äù Danielle added of her mom. ‚ÄúI hope she is proud of the way I handled everything.‚Äù

Russo, 61, was grabbing lunch just a half-block from her stationhouse on Sept. 29, 2022, when Zisopoulos walked out of his apartment building near 20th Avenue and 41st Street and suddenly rushed at Russo, whom he didn‚Äôt know, shoving her to the pavement and getting on top of her while clutching a serrated kitchen knife.

The killer chased away a bystander who tried to intervene and stabbed Russo nearly two dozen times in the chest and abdomen before fleeing to the apartment he shared with his mother.

Another bystander ran to a nearby EMS station for help, and Zisopoulos was quickly arrested in the attack ‚Äî which was captured on chilling surveillance footage.

A Queens jury convicted the killer May 19 after a 12-day trial.

‚ÄúAlison Russo was the best of the best: a longtime public servant and friend who has been missed every single day since her senseless murder in 2022,‚Äù city Fire Commissioner Robert Tucker said in a statement following the proceedings.

‚ÄúThis sentencing speaks to the brutality of the crime, and though it won‚Äôt bring her back, I pray it will finally give her family the closure they deserve,‚Äù he said.

Queens DA Melinda Katz said Russo will not be forgotten.

‚ÄúNew York will always remember FDNY EMS Captain Alison Russo as a hero, who ‚Äî for 24 years ‚Äî served our city and saved countless lives,‚Äù Katz said in a statement.

‚ÄúIn the dark days after September 11, she worked in search and recovery efforts in Lower Manhattan,‚Äù Katz said. ‚ÄúNothing will bring Captain Russo back, but we hope that the pain and grief over her loss will lessen with today‚Äôs sentencing.‚Äù

Danielle Russo told reporters, ‚ÄúThank God I can put this piece of the process behind me for a little bit.

‚ÄúObviously the situation will never go away. It‚Äôs something I have to live with every single day.

‚ÄúWhat you see going is all the support that I have from family, friends and the fire department,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt ask for anything more. Basically, they‚Äôve carried me through this process.‚Äù
item.author: Reuven Fenton, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂÖçË¥πËµ†ÈÄÅ10‰∏áÂº†Ê¢ÖË•øÁôæË¥ß7Êúà4Êó•ÁÉüËä±Ë°®ÊºîÈó®Á•®ÔºåÂèØÊ¨£ËµèÂ§©ÈôÖÁ∫øÁæéÊôØÔºåËé∑ÂèñÊñπÊ≥ïÂ¶Ç‰∏ã | NYC giving away 100K free tickets to Macy‚Äôs 4th of July fireworks show with skyline views ‚Äî here‚Äôs how to get them
item.description:
These lucky New Yorkers are going to have a blast.

The city is doling out 100,000 free tickets for prime views of the Macy‚Äôs 4th of July fireworks along the East River this week.

The passes ‚Äì to be distributed online on a first-come, first-serve basis ‚Äì will unlock access for 100,000 revelers to watch the grand show in Brooklyn Bridge Park or sections of Pier 16 and Pier 17 at the Seaport in Manhattan, Mayor Eric Adams announced Monday.

‚ÄúEvery New Yorker deserves a chance to celebrate under the sparkle of the Macy‚Äôs 4th of July Fireworks, and this year, 100,000 lucky residents will have front-row access to one of the city‚Äôs most iconic events as our city celebrates its 400th anniversary this year and we get ready to celebrate our nation‚Äôs 250th anniversary next year,‚Äù Adams said in a statement.¬†

The mayor credited his administration with making sure the ‚Äúcelebration is for everyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait to join hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers and visitors as we light up the night and honor America‚Äôs birthday right here in the greatest city in the world,‚Äù he added.

The city‚Äôs second annual free ticket allotment comes after the NYPD faced sharp criticism in years past for roping off areas for private watch parties while turning away members of the public without law-enforcement ties.

The no-charge tickets will be made available at 8:30 a.m. Tuesday, with users permitted to request up to four tickets. This year‚Äôs massive distribution offers 10 times the number of free tickets offered last year, when the fireworks show was moved to the West Side.

New Yorkers can text ‚ÄúFIREWORKS‚Äù directly to 917-909-2288 to secure tickets ahead of the general release to the public, with the first 2,500 to receive four free tickets to the Brooklyn Bridge Park location.

For those who are unable to score a freebies, the 49th annual fireworks display will be visible along FDR Drive.

Access points to the general public include:¬†

  • Montgomery Street and Madison Street¬†
  • Robert F. Wagner Sr. Place and Brooklyn Bridge On/Off Ramp¬†
  • Broad Street and Water Street

An ADA-accessible viewing spot will be provided on the Manhattan side at Murry Bergtraum Field with an entrance at Pike and Cherry streets.¬†

Widely recognized as the largest Independence Day celebration in the nation, the show will kickoff at 9:25 p.m., according to the city‚Äôs website.¬†

This year‚Äôs Macy‚Äôs 4th of July fireworks performance will feature more than 80,000 shells fired 1,000 feet into the air from barges along the East River.

Viewers can expect 11 new effects to debut this year ‚Äì like atomic rings, sunbursts, crackling crown jellyfish, comet fans and more ‚Äì as well as 30 vibrant colors and other visual effects like projection mapping on the Brooklyn Bridge.
item.author: Nicole Rosenthal

item.title: ËÆ®ÂéåËæõËæ£È£üÁâ©ÁöÑÁî®È§êËÄÖ‰ºöË¢´È§êÂéÖ‚ÄúÁæûËæ±‚Äù ‚Äî‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàË∑≥ËøásrirachaÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÁäØÁΩ™Ë°å‰∏∫Ôºü | Diners who hate spicy food feel ‚Äòheat shamed‚Äô by restaurants ‚Äî why is it a crime to skip the sriracha?
item.description:
For some, the spice ain‚Äôt nice.

Throughout her life, Jennifer Allerot, 53, has ordered the spiciest foods on the menu whenever she ate at a restaurant ‚Äî until she developed a stomach ulcer four years ago.¬†

‚ÄúI used to devour curry, but I can‚Äôt eat it anymore,‚Äù Allerot, an accountant in Morristown, New Jersey, told The Post. ‚ÄúIf I even get a taste of something spicy on my tongue, my stomach is, like, ‚ÄòOh, no,‚Äô and I have to reach for a Tums immediately to stop the pain.‚Äù

These days, it‚Äôs become a hot trend to spike the seasonings as the ‚Äúheat‚Äù quotient in every restaurant dish seems to be through the roof. Case in point: Tongue-tingly meals sporting chili pepper illustrations are dominating menus, flaming hot sauces are gracing tabletops, and fast-food restaurants like Wendy‚Äôs just upped the ante with their a Cajun Crunch Chicken Sandwich.

And it‚Äôs a badge of honor for celebrities to wolf down extra-hot foods on ‚ÄúHot Ones,‚Äù a YouTube show watched by millions ‚Äî plus, there was last year‚Äôs sriracha shortage.

At the same time, spice-averse diners have come under fire for giving waiters the third degree about how searing a dish is.

It‚Äôs the new heat-shaming movement, but when did it become a crime to skip the sriracha?

Don‚Äôt let it get heated

Even as the spicy dish trend heats up, Allerot hasn‚Äôt quit dining out. Instead, she says the best way to avoid a Scoville heat-level dish is to befriend the waitstaff, especially when she‚Äôs eating at a new restaurant.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt grill them, exactly,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúBut I find that if I tell a waiter, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm really sorry, but my stomach isn‚Äôt what it used to be,‚Äô that person is going to be really good at recommending what‚Äôs truly spicy and what isn‚Äôt.‚Äù

While most chefs are willing to dial it down, no toque wearer should ever ‚Äúheat shame‚Äù a customer, says Samuel-Drake Jones, chef of Hudson VU in Hell‚Äôs Kitchen.

‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs this feeling that you‚Äôre not as strong if you don‚Äôt eat spicy food,‚Äù Jones told The Post. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre fixated on this competition of who can eat the hottest foods, but when someone is dining at my restaurant and spending money to relax, I want to do my best to make that happen for that person.‚Äù

Peter He, the Michelin-starred chef at Meili, a Sichuan restaurant at Coda Williamsburg, says requests to adjust heat levels are routine, but heat-intolerant diners may lose the experience of tasting interesting flavors.

‚ÄúA well-prepared dish is usually crafted with a specific spice or heat level in mind, so modifying it too much can affect its overall taste and texture,‚Äù he told The Post.

Shannon Guthrie, 28, says she has ordered many dishes she thought were mild ‚Äî only to feel the heat immediately ‚Äî and it‚Äôs the mouth-burning aftereffects that she tries to avoid.

‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm done with my meal, I don‚Äôt want to keep feeling it,‚Äù Guthrie, who lives on the Upper West Side and works in marketing, told The Post, adding that, despite this, she has never sent a dish back to the kitchen.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll just eat whatever it is and suffer the consequences,‚Äù says Guthrie, who says she grew up in a ‚Äúspice-less‚Äù household.

‚ÄúFor me, this means chugging a lot of water.‚Äù

Still, Guthrie wants to keep trying new foods and asks for more customization when dining out.

‚ÄúLast week, I ordered a chicken taco dish at a Mexican restaurant, and asked if they could serve the spicy sauce on the side,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThe waiter was fine with it, which was good, because there is no way I would have been able to eat it otherwise.‚Äù

The goal isn‚Äôt to have diners breathing fire, chefs insist. In fact, there‚Äôs a big difference between the heat that derives from, say, chili powder and chiles themselves.

‚ÄúIndian food is full of spices, such as fenugreek leaves, turmeric, chili cumin and coriander powders, but that doesn‚Äôt mean the dish is spicy,‚Äù says Abishek Sharma, the chef at three restaurants, including Madam Ji Ki Shaadi in the Village and Swagat on the Upper East Side. ‚ÄúWe love it when customers ask us what‚Äôs in a dish because we want to people to understand the difference between something that‚Äôs hot and something that‚Äôs flavorful.‚Äù

Time your requests

The best way to tone down your taco is to mention your spice preferences when you place your order.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs better than us trying to modify something after it‚Äôs been prepared or brought to the table,‚Äù He says. ‚ÄúMaking your preferences known ahead of time also allows us to offer alternatives, like serving a side of starch to balance the heat.‚Äù

And, if you‚Äôre unfamiliar with a certain ingredient, it‚Äôs always best to Google it or ask what it is before ordering a dish, suggests Michael King, the chef at Sungold at Arlo Williamsburg, where a signature hot sauce and spicy condiments are made in-house.

‚ÄúWe tell¬†our servers to ensure that guests are aware that each ingredient is there for a reason and that some ‚Äòspicy‚Äô ingredients add depth, not just heat,‚Äù King told The Post.

Ultimately, most chefs are happiest when you‚Äôre happy ‚Äî just keep in mind that there are some dishes where it‚Äôs nonnegotiable to adjust the heat index.

‚ÄúWe control the amount of spice that goes into the food,‚Äù Sharma says. ‚ÄúOur chicken, pork and lamb vindaloo is meant to be spicy. There‚Äôs no changing it, so if you don‚Äôt like spicy, we‚Äôll urge you to order something milder, like our butter chicken.‚Äù

In this tongue-tingling age, Allerot urges diners to build a rapport with their server.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll start by raving about how much I love the restaurant and then I lean in and give my spiel,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWhen I say my tastebuds won‚Äôt be happy if I order something bland, but my tummy will, they usually get it right away.‚Äù
item.author: Lambeth Hochwald

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈ™ÑÂÇ≤Ê∏∏Ë°åÂêéÔºåÊó†ËæúÁöÑÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥Âú®Áü≥Â¢ôÈôÑËøëÁöÑÊû™Âáª‰∫ã‰ª∂‰∏≠Âèó‰º§‚ÄîËÄåÂ∞ÑÊùÄÂ•πÁöÑÂ•≥Â≠©‰πüÊÑèÂ§ñ‰∏≠ÂºπÔºöÊ∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫ê | Innocent teen wounded in shooting near Stonewall after NYC Pride ‚Äî while girl who shot her then accidentally takes bullet, too: sources
item.description:
An innocent 17-year-old girl was shot in Sunday night‚Äôs chaos outside Manhattan‚Äôs historic Stonewall Inn after the Pride parade ‚Äî while the 16-year-old who nailed her ended up accidentally shot herself by a pal, cops and sources said.

The mayhem erupted around 10:15 p.m. when the 16-year-old, who was with some people, opened fire at another group during a street beef on Sheridan Square, just around the corner from the LGBTQ+ landmarked bar in Greenwich Village, law enforcement sources said.¬†

The young shooter struck the 17-year-old girl ‚Äî a bystander who was not involved in the clash ‚Äî in the leg, sources said.¬†

Another person in the shooter‚Äôs group then fired at their rivals a second time ‚Äî but mistakenly hit her pal who fired the first shot, striking her in the head, sources said.

The 16-year-old girl was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where she was listed in critical condition, and the 17-year-old bystander to Northwell Greenwich Village Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, cops said.

No arrests have been made, and the investigation is ongoing. The violence is not considered hate crime-related, according to the sources.

Greenwich Village and specifically the Stonewall Inn, where the 1969 Stonewall Riots effectively marked the start of the country‚Äôs gay rights movement, has traditionally been at the heart of the city‚Äôs annual Pride celebration.

Mayor Eric Adams said he was briefed on the shooting after the parade in a statement he shared on social media.

‚ÄúSaddened to learn about the shooting by the Stonewall Inn tonight as Pride celebrations were winding down,‚Äù Adams said on X. ‚ÄúDuring a time when our city should be rejoicing and celebrating members of our diverse LGBTQ+ community, incidents like this are devastating.‚Äù

The shooting occurred several hours after a false report of gunfire during Pride celebrations at Washington Square Park sparked a stampede as thousands fled the packed greenspace.

A shirtless man had unleashed bear spray during or before the mad dash in the park and was taken into custody, police said.

The suspected sprayer, Dominick Sabater, 33, of Harlem was charged Monday with raps including assault, reckless endangerment and unlawful possession of a noxious material, cops said.

The Manhattan man claimed he whipped out the 8.1-ounce can of bear spray because he thought he was about to be jumped or get involved in a fight and used it as a deterrent to keep people away from him, authorities said.

More than 50 people were injured during the chaos ‚Äî either by the stampede or the potent chemical spray, according to law enforcement sources.

Sabater has one previous arrest in the city: a 2021 bust for unprovoked assault for reaching into a car around Union Square in Manhattan and striking a man inside in the right eye with a cellphone, police said. The men were strangers to each other, cops said.
item.author: Joe Marino, Larry Celona, Amanda Woods

item.title: Êñ∞ÁöÑÊ∏ÖÂçïÂ£∞Áß∞Ôºå‰∏ñÁïå‰∏ä‚ÄúÊúÄÂ•ΩÁöÑ‚ÄùÊä´Ëê®‰∏çÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ôºå‰ΩÜ‰∏ÄÂÆ∂Â§ßËãπÊûúÂ∫óÂáªË¥•‰∫ÜËÆ∏Â§öÊÑèÂ§ßÂà©È§êÂéÖ | World‚Äôs ‚Äòbest‚Äô pizza isn‚Äôt in NYC, new list claims ‚Äî but one Big Apple parlor beat out a slew of Italy spots
item.description:
They‚Äôre pan-tastic.

A new list naming the 100 best pizza spots in 2025 has been released, and sorry, New Yorkers ‚Äî¬†your favorite local parlor didn‚Äôt make it anywhere near number one.

Instead, the top five slots in the saucy new ranking were snatched up by spots in Italy ‚Äî¬†with the Big Apple edged all the way down to 17.

Gotham‚Äôs biggest cheese, according to The Best Pizza Awards, is the critically-acclaimed Una Pizza Napoletana.

Anthony Mangieri‚Äôs popular restaurant has been a regular presence on the generally well-regarded list, but this year, it moved up 11 places, beating out other sacred New York spots and claiming the real victory ‚Äî¬†best pizza in the U.S. (Take that, New Jersey and New Haven.)

Mangieri brought his first pie to the city in 2004, and has spent the past twenty-odd years perfecting his recipes in various locations both in and out of the city.

This award-winning spot keeps it simple with classic flavor combinations like Margherita, Bianca and Marinara pies ‚Äî no hot honey slices or ranch-related offerings, as Mangieri joked in an April Fool‚Äôs Instagram post earlier this year.

When it opened, Una Pizza Napoletana was a staple spot in the East Village. After a pandemic-era detour to New Jersey, the restaurant continues to draw lengthy lines and rave reviews in its current home on the Lower East Side.

Despite the restaurant‚Äôs success, the Garden State native refuses to franchise, sell or even delegate dough-making responsibilities.

‚ÄúNo one makes the dough in the restaurant, 25 years later, except for me,‚Äù Mangieri previously told The Post.‚ÄúEvery single pizza that people eat, I still make the dough in the morning myself.‚Äù

Other New York addresses making the cut included Lucali, Stretch Pizza, Don Antonio and Mama‚Äôs Too.

Another trendy local fave, L‚Äôindustrie, was handed a special 2025 Street Pizza Award ‚Äî in addition to its number 34 ranking on the main list.

One hot spot, Ceres, a new favorite of Barstool‚Äôs Dave Portnoy, didn‚Äôt make the grade this year.

In order to keep the competition fair, The Best Pizza, an offshoot of gastronomic organization The Best Chef, reportedly employs a strict voting and judging process.

The body of voters, selected by the organization, is made up of 150 industry professionals, including food critics and journalists, and 362 pizza chefs ‚Äî who are strictly forbidden from voting for colleagues or themselves ‚Äî from 60 different countries.

In addition, each vote is verified by the organization and held confidential by the voter themselves as well as the board.

While voters of The Best Pizza‚Äôs 2025 ranking clearly had love for Una Pizza, it‚Äôs far from the first time the pizzeria has reigned supreme.

In 2024, a competing list with its own supposedly strenuous nomination guidelines, 50 Top Pizza, ranked NYC institution Una Pizza Napoletana number one in the world.

The 10 best pizzerias in the world, according to The Best Pizza Awards

  1. I Masanielli, Caserta, Italy
  2. Pepe in Grani, Calazzo, Italy
  3. Pizzarium, Rome, Italy
  4. Bob Alchimia a Spicchi, Montepaone, Italy
  5. I Tigli, San Bonifacio, Italy
  6. The Pizza Bar on 38th, Tokyo, Japan
  7. 180 grammi, Rome, Italy
  8. Sartoria Panatieri, Barcelona, Spain
  9. Mater, Fiano Romano, Italy
  10. Pizza Studio Tamaki, Tokyo, Japan
item.author: Caroline Cubbin

item.title: Sean ‚ÄúDiddy‚Äù CombsÂæàÂø´Â∞±‰ºöÁü•ÈÅì‰ªñÁöÑÂëΩËøêÔºåÈô™ÂÆ°ÂëòÂºÄÂßãÂÆ°ËÆÆÈáçÁ£ÖÁÇ∏ÂºπÊÄßË¥©ËøêÂÆ°Âà§ | Sean ‚ÄòDiddy‚Äô Combs could soon learn his fate as jurors begin deliberations in bombshell sex-trafficking trial
item.description:
Sean ‚ÄúDiddy‚Äù Combs could soon learn his fate as jurors in his bombshell Manhattan trial began deliberating Monday, following nearly two months of sensational testimony.

The panelists, eight men and four women, were sent to the jury room around 11:30 a.m. to begin weighing the five felony charges against the Bad Boys Records founder ‚Äî in a case alleging he forced women to have sex with male prostitutes in what became known as ‚Äúfreak-offs.‚Äù

Jurors heard from 34 prosecution witnesses over the last seven weeks of testimony, including Combs‚Äô then-pregnant ex-girlfriend Cassie Ventura and another former gal pal, who took the stand under the pseudonym ‚ÄúJane.‚Äù

The panel was also presented with mountains of evidence, including hundreds of text messages and hours of sexually explicit footage of the ‚Äúfreak-offs,‚Äù which jurors viewed on screens that were blocked off to the press and public.

Prosecutors repeatedly played in open court the infamous video of Combs beating up Ventura in a Los Angeles hotel hallway in 2016.

Combs, 55, has been held at a Brooklyn lockup since his September 2024 arrest and was seated with his lawyers at the defense table throughout the stunning proceedings, with his mother and children sometimes showing up to court in his support.

The disgraced music mogul is charged with two sex-trafficking counts, one racketeering conspiracy count and two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution.

He faces up to life in prison if convicted on just one of the racketeering or sex-trafficking charges.

Ventura testified for four days during the first week of trial about her tumultuous, on-and-off relationship with the ‚ÄúI‚Äôll Be Missing You‚Äù rapper, claiming he regularly roughed her up and pressured her to take part in ‚Äúfreak-offs‚Äù while she was on drugs.

She also claimed he threatened to release videos he took of the sex marathons in order to get her to continue participating in the frequent sessions.

Prosecutors alleged that Combs ran a criminal enterprise for 20 years, using his employees to carry out a slew of crimes, like ensuring that he always had an array of drugs on hand for the ‚Äúfreak-offs,‚Äù kidnapping a member of his staff, witness tampering and bribery.

The ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs All About the Benjamins‚Äù rhymer also allegedly broke into rapper Kid Cudi‚Äôs home and had his car bombed with a Molotov cocktail after discovering Ventura briefly dated him.

Combs, who did not testify in his own defense, has pleaded not guilty.

His attorneys claim that the women took part in the ‚Äúfreak-offs‚Äù consensually.

Manhattan federal Judge Arun Subramanian instructed the jurors on the law first thing Monday morning before releasing them to start their work.
item.author: Ben Kochman, Priscilla DeGregory

item.title: ‚ÄúÊÉäÊÖåÂ§±Êé™‚ÄùÁöÑÂè≤Âù¶È°øÂ≤õÊ∞ëÂú®ÁãÇÈáéÁöÑËΩ¶ÈÅìÂØπÂÜ≥‰∏≠Ë¢´ÊÑ§ÊÄíÁöÑÁÅ´È∏°ËøΩÈÄê | ‚ÄòFreaked out‚Äô Staten Islander chased by furious turkey in wild driveway showdown caught on camera
item.description:
Talk about fowl play.

A Staten Island man found himself in a wild confrontation when a feisty turkey chased him around his driveway in a bird-brained showdown caught on camera.

Noel Colon had just stepped out of his house and was heading to work when the winged menace swooped in from behind and aggressively flapped after him all the way to his car, the Staten Island Advance reported.

‚ÄúOh s‚Äìt,‚Äù a frenzied Colon could be heard saying in the chaotic home surveillance footage.

The Grasmere man, thinking he was in the clear after losing sight of the angry bird, opened his driver‚Äôs side door of his white Ford SUV ‚Äî only for the beaked bully to pop up right behind it.

The berserk gobbler continued flapping after Colon, who was seen frantically sprinting around his driveway screaming expletives, while wearing a backpack and carrying a shopping bag and what appeared to be a large wrapped gift.

The National Grid worker, who eventually managed to jump into his truck and drive away, said the crazed encounter nearly gave him a ‚Äúheart attack.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm usually never afraid with anything that happens in life,‚Äù he told the local outlet.

‚ÄúI just got with the flow. But that was something that was just completely, completely unexpected and I was freaked out. I was concerned with just getting to work on time.‚Äù

Colon said he initially tried to avoid disturbing the turkey when he spotted it on his walkway, but things went sideways when the feathered fiend let out a noise and charged at him.

He later found 11 eggs near where the crazed chase unfolded and realized his avian attacker was likely protecting its unborn poults.

‚ÄúThey turkey, she comes back every morning around 6:30 until like 7:30 a.m. and she hangs out there in the morning,‚Äù Colon told the outlet.

‚ÄúSo I didn‚Äôt want to move the eggs, because that‚Äôs hers. Now, when I see a turkey, I walk across the street.‚Äù
item.author: Anna Young

item.title: Âú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂÖ¨Âõ≠‰∏æË°åÁöÑÈ™ÑÂÇ≤ËÅö‰ºöÊúüÈó¥Ôºå 50Â§öÂêçËµ§Ë£∏‰∏äË∫´ÁöÑÁî∑Â≠êÈáäÊîæÁÜäÂñ∑ÈõæÔºåÈÄ†ÊàêË∏©Ë∏è‰∫ã‰ª∂ | More than 50 injured after shirtless man unleashes bear spray during Pride gathering in NYC park, causing stampede
item.description:
More than 50 people were injured during a Pride celebration at Washington Square Park Sunday evening when false reports of gunfire and the deployment of bear spray sparked a stampede of people fleeing for their lives, according to police and sources.

A shirtless man unleashed the potent chemicals in the park ‚Äî burning several bystanders‚Äô eyes ‚Äî at the same time, rumors of gunfire led thousands to rush out of the Greenwich Village park, believing their lives were in danger.

The man was arrested by police at the scene, according to the NYPD.

It wasn‚Äôt immediately clear how many injuries were a result of the stampede and how many were due to the mace, but none were expected to be life-threatening.

Police estimated that there were roughly 10,000 people in the park at the time. Many rushed through the park in a panic and busted through police barriers.

The suspect apparently thought that he was going to be jumped, so he panicked and sprayed the bear mace in self-defense, sources told The Post.

Many attendees at the park had no idea what was happening, celebrants lingering near the park after the chaos told The Post.

Some thought that they heard popping and ran on instinct, figuring someone had opened fire on the crowd.

‚ÄúWe all thought some fanatic with a gun was shooting people, so of course we all ran in whatever direction would get us out of the park the fastest. But because there were thousands and thousands of people, you had all these barricades up preventing you from making the fastest escape. So we all had to file out in an organized fashion, which no one wanted to do because we were all scared,‚Äù Omari Loftin, a 20-year-old from Washington Heights, said.

Loftin said that he saw multiple people with various injuries, including some flushing their eyes out and one young man with blood running down the side of his head.

Others said the barricades did more harm than good while they were trying to escape, and even contributed to some of the chaos.

‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs dancing, everyone‚Äôs partying, and then everyone‚Äôs screaming. My friends and I didn‚Äôt know what happened, but word going around was that there were gunshots. I didn‚Äôt hear gunshots, but when you hear the word ‚Äògunshots,‚Äô that‚Äôs all you really need to get yourself the f‚Äìk out of there,‚Äù Isaiah Whitehurst, 23, of Bedford Stuyvesant said.

‚ÄúThere was a stampede. People were screaming, tripping all over themselves. Cops were trying to clear the park, but there was barricades up and everyone‚Äôs getting pushed up so tight against the barricades and it‚Äôs like a bottleneck.‚Äù

An investigation into the mace incident is ongoing.

Every year, the Pride Parade through Manhattan ends at Washington Square Park, where many spend the day leaping in and out of the fountain.

Hours after the chaos, two people were shot outside the landmarked LGBTQ bar, The Stonewall Inn, which was hosting Pride celebrations all day long into the night.

While the day is largely celebratory, violence among groups has broken out in recent years.

Last year, multiple brawls broke out throughout the day from morning to night, leading to 22 arrests.

In 2022, one reveler at the park decided to light a batch of fireworks shortly after nightfall during a pro-choice rally that coincided with Pride, but many confused the popping with gunshots and made a run for it, sparking a stampede similar to the one observed Sunday.
item.author: Reuven Fenton, Larry Celona, Caitlin McCormack

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶È™ÑÂÇ≤Ê∏∏Ë°åÂêéÔºåÂú®ÂéÜÂè≤ÊÇ†‰πÖÁöÑÁü≥Â¢ôÈÖíÂ∫óÂ§ñÊãçÊëÑ2Âº†ÁÖßÁâá | 2 shot outside historic Stonewall Inn following NYC Pride March
item.description:
Two people were shot near the historic Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village Sunday night following the Big Apple‚Äôs Pride parade earlier in the day, according to police.

A man shot is in critical condition, fighting for his life and a woman who was shot in the leg is stable after being transported to a local hospital, sources told The Post.

Officers responded to a report of shots fired just around the corner from the LGBTQ+ landmarked bar around 10:15 p.m.

It wasn‚Äôt immediately clear if the shooting was targeted ‚Äî including whether it was a hate crime ‚Äî or how many suspects were involved.

No arrests have been made and the investigation is ongoing.

Mayor Eric Adams said he was briefed on the shooting in a statement he shared on social media.

‚ÄúSaddened to learn about the shooting by the Stonewall Inn tonight as Pride celebrations were winding down,‚Äù Adams said on X. ‚ÄúDuring a time when our city should be rejoicing and celebrating members of our diverse LGBTQ+ community, incidents like this are devastating.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre praying for the speedy recovery of the victims in tonight‚Äôs shooting,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúThe NYPD will work quickly and tirelessly to bring the suspects to justice.‚Äù

This is a breaking story. Please check back for updates.
item.author: Joe Marino, Larry Celona, Caitlin McCormack

item.title: ÈÜâÈÖíÂè∏Êú∫Êíû‰∏äËíôÊâòÂÖãËâ∫ÊúØÂ±ïÔºå‰∏Ä‰∏æËµî‰∏ä10‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÔºöË≠¶ÂØü | Drunk driver crashes into ritzy Montauk art show, racks up $100K in damages in one stroke: cops
item.description:
An accused drunk driver caused at least $100,000 in damages after crashing through an upscale Montauk art show on Long Island early Sunday morning, according to reports.

Nicoly Ribeiro De Souza, 23, was hit with drunken driving charges and six counts of reckless mischief after police said the allegedly tipsy driver plowed a 2020 Nissan Rogue into the exhibits around 3 a.m., Newsday reported.

Sag Harbor photographer Jim Levison told the outlet that it ‚Äúlooked like a tornado came through.‚Äù

Photos from the scene show six white display tents smashed and some of the artwork, including paintings, strewn about at the event, which is sponsored by Montauk Artists Association and features the work of local and regional artists.

‚ÄúThe people that come to these shows, this is how they make their living,‚Äù John Papaleo, who sits on the association‚Äôs executive board, told Newsday. ‚ÄúThis is their livelihood.‚Äù

One of the damaged tents displayed the work of about 30 artists, and one participating artist lost works that she had been working on for the past eight months, Levison said.

The art show opened Friday, and about 50 volunteers chipped in to clean up the wreckage so the show could go on on schedule on Sunday.

No one involved in the show was hurt in the early morning mishap.

De Souza, who was awaiting arraignment on Sunday, was taken to Southampton Hospital with minor injuries, local outlet Greater Long Island said.

A passenger in the Nissan refused medical attention at the scene.
item.author: Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: ÂÖ±ÂíåÂÖö‰∫∫Êù∞ÂÖã¬∑ÊÅ∞Â°îÈõ∑Âà©Ôºà Jack Ciattarelli ÔºâÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÂèçÂØπË∑®ÊÄßÂà´‰∏ª‰πâËµ¢ÂæóÊñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûÊîøÂ∫úÁöÑÁ´ûÈÄâÔºöÊñ∞ÁöÑÊ∞ëÊÑèË∞ÉÊü• | Republican Jack Ciattarelli can win NJ gov‚Äôs race by opposing transgenderism: new poll
item.description:
Republican Jack Ciattarelli can win the New Jersey governor‚Äôs race this fall by campaigning against transgenderism, a new poll suggests.

The survey, conducted for the conservative American Principles Project, found that 68% of Garden State voters oppose allowing biological boys who identify as transgender to compete against girls in sports, while just 22% support transgender participation.

More than 70% of New Jersey residents also oppose taxpayer funding for gender transition or sex reassignment surgery for minors, while just 20% expressed support.

In addition, 60% of voters oppose public elementary schools teaching about sexual orientation and transgender ideology, while 31% back such instruction, according to the survey of 500 likely voters by Cygnal.

Ciattarelli is facing off against the Democratic nominee for governor, Rep. Mikie Sherrill, who is on record supporting transgender rights. They are vying to replace Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy, who is term-limited and can‚Äôt run again.

In the poll‚Äôs initial surveying of voters, Sherrill leads Ciattarelli 50% to 43%, with the remaining 7% undecided.

Voters are then told of Sherrill‚Äôs position on transgender rights and other issues.

‚ÄúAnti-Women‚Äôs Sports: In Congress, Mikie Sherrill voted to let boys who identify as
girls compete in girls‚Äô sports,‚Äù one statement said.

Sherrill also backed legislation that would ‚Äúopen women‚Äôs restrooms, locker rooms, and
private spaces‚Äù to biological men or transgender individuals, ‚Äúadvancing a radical agenda at the expense of safety for girls and women,‚Äù another statement read to voters said.

Respondents were told that Sherrill wants to ban therapists from talking to children about their biological sex, instead ‚Äúforcing radical gender ideology on young kids over their parents‚Äô objections.‚Äù

The race then turns into a dead heat ‚Äî 46% for Sherill to 45% for Ciattarelli ‚Äî after voters are informed of Sherrill‚Äôs positions on transgender issues.

‚ÄúThe polling is clear, New Jersey families are fed up with the far-left‚Äôs woke, anti-family agenda,‚Äù said American Principles Project president Terry Schilling in a statement. ‚ÄúNow is the time for us to work together and flip New Jersey red so common sense can return to their state.

‚ÄúThe path to victory in New Jersey for Ciattarelli is messaging on the Culture War. This
polling is proof that people in purple and blue states care deeply about protecting their
families and will vote accordingly.‚Äù

The APP said, ‚ÄúTransgender and parental rights issues should drive the narrative of the race‚Äù because the issues cut across across party lines.

The poll also found that 53% of Jersey voters say the state is on the wrong track, while just 35%
said it‚Äôs heading in the right direction.

A majority of voters ‚Äî 53% ‚Äî also said pocketbook concerns including inflation/cost of living and taxes and government spending are the most pressing problem.

Another 11% of voters cited illegal immigration and border security as most important.

The survey was conducted for APP by pollster Cygnal with 500 likely general election voters on June 19-20. It has a margin of error of ¬±4.36% points. Voters were interviewed through an online panel or mobile phone text.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: ‰∏Ä‰ΩçÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶ÂÖ±ÂíåÂÖö‰∫∫Âú®ÂèØËÉΩÁöÑÂàùÈÄâ‰∏≠Â§ßÂπÖÈ¢ÜÂÖàÔºåÈù¢ÂØπÂ∑ûÈïøKathy Hochul ÔºöÊ∞ëÊÑèË∞ÉÊü• | One NY Republican opens massive lead in possible primary to face Gov. Kathy Hochul: poll
item.description:
Upstate Rep. Elise Stefanik has a massive edge over other Republicans in a hypothetical party primary to take on Gov. Kathy Hochul next year, a new poll found.

Some 64% of Republicans would support Stefanik ‚Äî while only 8% would back Hudson Valley Rep. Michael Lawler, the survey of 1,108 likely Republican voters conducted by the firm co/efficient found.

Another 6% polled said they‚Äôd support Nassau County Executive Bruce Blakeman in a hypothetical matchup, while 22% are undecided or back another candidate ahead of the 2026 gubernatorial race.

‚ÄúAmong the most likely contenders Congresswoman Elise Stefanik is widely known AND widely loved,‚Äù co/efficient pollster Ryan Munce said. ‚ÄúOver the last several years, Stefanik has become a fixture in both statewide and nationwide politics and is the face of change for New York State.‚Äù

Still, Munce was surprised that Stefanik amassed a 56- percentage point lead over Lawler, a popular lawmaker and also a rising star in the GOP.

‚ÄúIf I had my chips on the table, I thought Lawler would be in the mid-20s percent,‚Äù Munce told The Post.

‚ÄúTypically, this early in an election cycle, a significant percentage of voters are still undecided and waiting to see who else may join the race,‚Äù the pollster added. ‚ÄúToday in New York, that is not the case. Minds are made up and Elise Stefanik looks all but guaranteed to be the Republicans‚Äô choice to become the next Governor of New York.‚Äù

Stefanik, Lawler and Blakeman are eyeing a run for governor against the Democratic incumbent but no formal campaigns have kicked off ‚Äî yet.

Stefanik, first elected to the House in 2014, has more widespread name recognition and popularity among Republican voters than Lawler or Blakeman, according to the poll.

For example, 64% of Republicans had a favorable view of Stefanik, 11% an unfavorable view and 24% had no opinion or did not know her.

By comparison, 25% of Republicans had a favorable view of Lawler, 9% an unfavorable view but a whopping 66% were unsure or never heard of him, the poll showed.

Blakeman was viewed favorably by 17% of Republicans, unfavorably by 11% and 72% were unsure or never heard of him, according to the survey.

Munce attributed some of Stefanik‚Äôs edge to the fact she is chairwoman of the House Republican Leadership and has a higher national profile because she has served in GOP House leadership for a number of years.

She was also nominated to be President Trump‚Äôs US Ambassador to the United Nations ‚Äî but the president withdrew the selection earlier this year over concerns he needed her vote in Congress as the GOP holds only a razor-thin majority in the House.

Stefanik also had a prominent role grilling Ivy League college presidents over anti-Israel campus protests and antisemitism.

Trump suggested he was leaning toward giving Stefanik his blessing last month when he posted to TruthSocial an unsolicited endorsement of Lawler‚Äôs re-election campaign for Congress ‚Äî even though the lawmaker hasn‚Äôt announced his intentions for 2026.

Lawler took a jaunt upstate two weeks ago, making stops in six counties and meeting with over a dozen county GOP committee chairs, as well as elected officials and other party faithful.

Several of the local Republican leaders who met with Lawler said they would be happy to back him should he choose to go up against Hochul next year.

One survey by Harper Polling claimed that Lawler ‚Äî who represents the battleground 17th House District that takes in Rockland, Putnam and and portions of Westchester and Dutchess counties ‚Äî would have a better shot at defeating Hochul than Stefanik, whose 21st District in the North Country borders both Vermont and Canada.

Lawler‚Äôs camp, when informed of the GOP primary poll, said Sunday the congressman is the stronger candidate in the general election.

‚ÄúThe real race is against Kathy Hochul and the data universally shows that Mike Lawler is the only Republican who can defeat her and actually get elected governor,‚Äù Lawler campaign spokesman Chris Russell said.

Lawler, first elected to Congress in 2022, has been a vocal critic of the controversial congestion pricing toll to enter Manhattan and has fought to increase the state and local tax deduction on federal returns for New Yorkers that was capped during Trump‚Äôs first term as president.

Munce anticipates that Stefanik, Lawler or a generic Republican would poll well against Kathy Hochul, given the governor‚Äôs underwhelming public approval ratings in surveys.

The co/efficient survey was conducted from June 18-20 via mobile texts and landline interviews and has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.76% points.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈ™ÑÂÇ≤Ê∏∏Ë°åÂÖÖÊª°‰∫ÜÈó™Èó™ÂèëÂÖâÂíåÊ¨¢‰πêÁöÑË°óÈÅì‚Äî‰ΩÜÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂ±ÄÁöÑÊ∏∏Ë°åËÄÖ‰ªçÁÑ∂Ë¢´Á¶ÅÊ≠¢Á©øÂà∂Êúç | NYC Pride parade fills streets with glitter and glee ‚Äî but wannabe NYPD marchers still banned from wearing uniforms
item.description:
More than a million people filled Manhattan on Sunday for the largest annual Pride parade in North America ‚Äî while LGBTQ cops turned out in droves to protest from the sidelines.

As revelers dressed in glitter, drag and other festive attire packed the streets surrounding the downtown parade route, the officers were furious that they are still barred from marching in their NYPD uniforms.

‚ÄúIt takes a tremendous amount of courage to be out. It takes an even more tremendous amount of courage to be out in uniform,‚Äù said NYPD Detective Brian Downey, president of the Gay Officers Action League.

But the party remained uninterrupted for the throngs of sanctioned participants as the parade snaked through Madison Square Park, down Fifth Avenue, through Greenwich Village and up Seventh Avenue ‚Äî with rainbow flags and smiles flying from start to finish.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm out here making sure our voices are loud and proud and heard. It‚Äôs more important now than ever,‚Äù said 30-year-old Audacity Mansfield, who wore a ‚ÄúMr. Gay New Jersey‚Äù sash won at a pageant earlier this month.

‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt have pride, then we don‚Äôt really have anything,‚Äù Mansfield said. ‚ÄúIf we can‚Äôt be proud of who we are or if we can‚Äôt be proud of our community, what are we out here for?‚Äù

This year‚Äôs parade fell on the 10th anniversary of the legalization of gay marriage in the US and also commemorated the 1969 Stonewall riots ‚Äî which helped spark the country‚Äôs gay-rights movement ‚Äî with the theme ‚ÄúRise Up: Pride in Protest.‚Äù

But one part of the queer community that was left out of the festivities for the fifth year in a row were uniformed LGBTQ NYPD officers who were told by organizers they couldn‚Äôt march in their blues.

‚ÄúWe will not be erased,‚Äù read signs carried by cops watching from the sidelines, along with others reading, ‚ÄúLet gay cops back into march,‚Äù and, ‚ÄúOur uniform is our protest.‚Äù

NYPD Commissioner Jessica Tisch turned out to support the officers, calling the decision to bar them ‚Äúunbelievable.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is an absolute disgrace,‚Äù Tisch said, saying it was ironic that a parade about inclusivity is keeping people out. ‚ÄúThese officers standing behind me who have been pillars of reform in the community for decades have been excluded and told they are not welcome to walk in the uniforms they wear.‚Äù

The ban was put in place in 2021 over ongoing anti-cop sentiment from the George Floyd protests the summer before.

Parade organizer Heritage Pride claims it doesn‚Äôt want parade-marching officers carrying weapons, which they have to have on them as part of their uniform requirements.

Scores of on-duty armed cops protect the parade-goers.

Tisch called organizers‚Äô excuse ‚Äúnonsense‚Äù and characterized it as a ‚Äúpublicity stunt.‚Äù

‚ÄúHeritage of Pride knows full well that when officers wear their uniforms, those uniforms can be magnets,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt is about personal safety for our officers and public safety that officers don their uniforms and carry their service weapons with them.‚Äù

Downey said it was ‚Äúpainful‚Äù to have to protest the parade ‚Äî and that queer officers are among the most courageous members of the community.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been painful for four years now,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTelling folks that they can show up not as they are is not in the spirit of pride.‚Äù

‚ÄúEveryone standing behind me protests every day by going into the system that has historically was not for them. They go in and force change upon that system. They force that system to deal with that,‚Äù Downey added.

Downey ‚Äî echoing others ‚Äî also said it was outrageous that the parade would ask the NYPD to keep the parade safe but wouldn‚Äôt let officers march in uniform.

Mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani stopped by the protest and greeted Tisch and some protesting cops ‚Äî but was snubbed by at least two officers.

Mayor Eric Adams ‚Äî who previously voiced support for GOAL‚Äôs push to let officers march in uniform ‚Äî joined the parade but was booed at times and given the middle finger as he walked.

‚ÄúEric Adams doesn‚Äôt care about gay people!‚Äù a woman yelled, while others called him a ‚ÄúTrump lover‚Äù and screamed, ‚ÄúMamdani for mayor.‚Äù

Despite the controversy, Sunday‚Äôs parade was the festive and positive celebration many wait all year and travel from across the world to attend.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just proud of the energy,‚Äù said paradegoer Paul Mcgrorety. ‚ÄúI love seeing smiles and just the pridefulness of everyone here. It‚Äôs awesome to be here.‚Äù
item.author: Steven Vago, Alex Oliveira

item.title: ÂèëÁé∞Ê≠ªËÄÖÊºÇÊµÆÂú®ÂìàÂæ∑ÈÄäÊ≤≥‰∏ä | Dead man found floating in Hudson River
item.description:
A dead man was found floating in the Hudson River off Harlem on Sunday morning, police said.

Cops were called to the scene near Dyckman Street around the Henry Hudson Parkway shortly after 9:30 a.m. and found the body in the water, an NYPD rep said.

Cops from the 34th Precinct, as well as firefighters and the NYPD harbor and marine units, responded to the scene.

Post photos show workers from the coroner‚Äôs office hauling the corpse away in a body bag.

Police said the identity of the man, described by sources as being in his 40s, is pending further investigation and that his cause of death will be determined by the city medical examiner‚Äôs office.

Earlier this month, authorities pulled three bodies from the East River in one day, including that of a¬†15-year-old girl who vanished¬†off Roosevelt Island the week before, police said.

Grace Ilogene‚Äôs body was spotted floating in the fast-moving river June 6, swept away by the current after telling a friend she was going for a dip even though she couldn‚Äôt swim.¬†

Cops also responded to a 911 call about an unconscious man in the water just after 6 a.m. near the Brooklyn Bridge that day, and he was pronounced dead at the scene.

The same day, another man was spotted by a 911 caller floating in the water near 34th Street and FDR Drive just before 7 p.m. He was taken to Pier 16 and pronounced dead, police said.¬†
item.author: Larry Celona, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: Êõ¥Â§öÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁöÑÁãóÂú®Ê≤°Êúâ‰ªª‰ΩïÂêéÊûúÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÂèóÂà∞‰º§ÂÆ≥ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂõΩÂÆ∂Ê≥ïÊ°àÂÖ≥Èó≠‰∫ÜÊ≥ïÂæãÊºèÊ¥ûÊëä‰ΩçÔºö ‚Äú‰∏çÂ∫îËØ•ÂèëÁîü‚Äù | More NYC dogs mauled without consequence as state bill to close legal loophole stalls: ‚ÄòShould not be happening‚Äô
item.description:
City dogs continue to be mauled by other pooches without consequence because a state bill prompted by the horrific Penny the Chihuahua attack has stalled, animal activists say.

Upper West Side resident Jennifer Busse told The Post a pit bull who was illegally off his leash mauled her tiny 13-year-old shih tzu-chihuahua mix Forrest in Riverside Park earlier this month ‚Äî and that the NYPD said there are still no avenues in the criminal-justice system to punish the four-legged attacker‚Äôs careless owner.

‚ÄúSomething needs to change,‚Äù Busse fumed.

She said Forrest was sleeping in the grass at the Manhattan park June 6 when he was suddenly pounced on by the pit bull in front of her screaming terrified children, ages 6 and 8.

Busse said her poor pooch lost vision in his right eye while being left with more than a dozen puncture wounds from the attack.

Yet cops said their hands were tied, according to Busse.

‚ÄúDue to current laws, harm or death to an animal caused by another animal is not a criminal matter,‚Äù an NYPD rep confirmed to The Post.

The attack occurred just weeks after a similar incident involving Penny the Chihuahua on the Upper West Side made national headlines.

The 16-pound Chihuahua was mauled by a pair of pit bulls near Columbus Avenue on May 3.

The case prompted state Assemblywoman Jennifer Rajkumar last month to introduce a bill that seeks to allow owners to be potentially criminally charged for pet-on-pet injuries, as opposed to only facing a possible civil lawsuit.

‚ÄúPets are not property, they are family,‚Äù Rajkumar said at the time.

But the legislation remains stalled in the Assembly‚Äôs Agriculture Committee, although it‚Äôs unclear exactly why.

The bill would make it possible to levy charges against careless owners, including ‚Äúcruelty to animals through negligent handling of a dog‚Äù and ‚Äúleaving the scene of an animal attack.‚Äù

It would also impose harsher penalties for those who repeatedly violate city leash laws.

The bill is named after Penny.

‚ÄúThis lack of accountability has permitted numerous dog owners to allow their pets to attack other dogs,‚Äù Rajkumar said last month. ‚ÄúThe same owners will allow the behavior repeatedly, often dismissing it as ‚Äòplaying‚Äô or ‚Äòa dog being a dog.‚Äô ‚Äù

Busse said, ‚ÄúI totally understand that people who are homeless have [some of] these animals for companionship for protection.

‚ÄúBut at a certain point, this kind of situation is so unsafe for the community.‚Äù
item.author: Nicole Rosenthal

item.title: ÈùûÊ≥ïÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÊ±ΩËΩ¶ËßÅÈù¢‰ºöÔºå‰ª•ËÑ±Ë°£ËàûÂ•≥„ÄÅÊØíÂìÅÂíåÂºÄËÄ≥ÊúµÊâ¨Â£∞Âô®Á≥ªÁªü‰∏∫ÁâπËâ≤ÔºåËÆ©Â±ÖÊ∞ëÂèëÁñØ | Illegal NYC car meetups feature strippers, drugs and ear-splitting speaker systems driving residents nuts
item.description:
They‚Äôve heard just about enough of this.

Ear-splitting, high-decibel street parties fueled by cars with booming sound systems are making life hell for residents from the Bronx to Brooklyn ‚Äî as the massive automotive meetups are becoming an ever-more frequent nuisance.

The unregulated revelries are often louder than planes landing at LaGuardia and feature drugs, booze, strippers and wet t-shirt contests, all within earshot of neighborhoods such as Maspeth in Queens, Greenpoint in Brooklyn and Throggs Neck in the Bronx, residents said.

‚ÄúIt sounds like a missile being launched at your home from all directions,‚Äù said Astoria resident Jay Cane, 40.

‚ÄúYou know it will be a long night when the windows are vibrating.

‚ÄúYou shut your windows and turn on air conditioners and fans to drown out the noise, even in the winter,‚Äù the frustrated local said.

The events, which got their start during the COVID-19 pandemic, often last all hours of the night, as sounds blast from gigantic car-mounted speakers referred to as ‚Äúkitipo‚Äù systems.

Residents tormented by the noise of the illicit meetups ‚Äî which can feature dozens of cars paying to participate ‚Äî said the city and cops are having little luck cracking down on them.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a sense we‚Äôre being forgotten by the city because we have exhausted all the options it has provided, and we‚Äôre losing hope,‚Äù Cane said.

John DiMario, co-owner of Village Chapels funeral home in Middle Village, said the ruckus
could wake the dead.

‚ÄúIt booms off every surface in my house,‚Äù said DiMario, who lives in Maspeth. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been going
on for so long, and lately, it‚Äôs starting earlier.‚Äù

Alfredo Centola, co-founder of the nonprofit We Love Whitestone, said he and his family deal several times a week with intrusive noise from unlawful rendezvous in Willets Point and World‚Äôs Fair Marina in Queens, as well as Ferry Point in The Bronx.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a constant and consistent boom, boom, boom overnight,‚Äù said Centola, 54. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the most frustrating experience in the world.‚Äù

Locals said the events‚Äô organizers assemble in Industrial Business Zones and ‚Äúmixed-use‚Äù areas that are abandoned at night. There have been large-scale meetups outside of Vaughn College in East Elmhurst, Queens, and Maspeth‚Äôs UPS Customer Center, as well as on Randall‚Äôs Island ‚Äî within walking distance of NYPD parking.

The gatherings also feature the illegal sale of ‚Äúnutcrackers,‚Äù a street cocktail made of alcohol and fruit punch, and ‚Äúendless pot smoking,‚Äù neighbors claim.

In one case, there have been reports of roughly 10 cars equipped with roaring stereos, synchronized by Bluetooth, routinely gathering in Greenpoint underneath the Kosciuszko Bridge.

‚ÄúThere is noise three or four times a week when there aren‚Äôt events in ‚ÄòUnder The K Bridge Park,‚Äô ‚Äù said Natalia Rzeszutek, 23, of eastern Greenpoint. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs mostly on weekends, but you have Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday nights where this has been a big issue,‚Äù too.

In The Bronx, Friends of Ferry Point Park President Dorothea Poggi¬†said these intolerable meetups frequently invade areas around the park, creating ‚Äúa hot spot for crime‚Äù where things sometimes turn violent.

‚ÄúPeople are making big money using the park and the streets as a venue; they aren‚Äôt paying the overhead to host a party, but they charge hundreds of people admission,‚Äù Poggi said. ‚ÄúThere are drugs and alcohol; they‚Äôve had strippers and wet t-shirt contests; there was even sex going on ‚Äì it‚Äôs crazy.‚Äù

An upcoming expected epic meetup ‚Äì touted as an ‚Äúoutdoor music car show battle‚Äù ‚Äì is planned for July 13 from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. in Jamaica, Queens. An online ticket-seller lists general admission as $25, while the cost for vendors is more than $535.

Centola, Poggi and Rzeszutek are all members of the Facebook group ‚ÄúThat Annoying Bass Sound Throughout NYC,‚Äù which Cane created to share tips about the illegal noise compromising their comfort.

When meetups occur, page members request that people place 311 calls in the hope that their reports will be prioritized.

‚ÄúThe group was formed by fed-up residents who want to end the underground meetups,‚Äù Cane said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all waiting for legislation to address these illegal speakers.‚Äù

Alicia Vaichunas, deputy chief of staff for city Councilman Robert Holden and a candidate for city council herself, lives near a regular nuisance in Maspeth and is active in the Facebook group. She said a Maspeth woman who tried to confront the source of the noise was threatened with a baseball bat.

‚ÄúThis happens at three or four Maspeth locations alone,‚Äù Vaichunas said. ‚ÄúIf the police chase them, they‚Äôll switch locations, and then we have to get the cops back out there again.‚Äù

In March 2024, Holden introduced a bill that would have increased civil penalties for unreasonable noise from personal audio devices. He said there has been success in curbing parties in some parks but adds that the NYPD needs more power to mute the meetups.

‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôve been doing on the local level is trying to get the police to confiscate,‚Äù Holden said. ‚ÄúI told police Commissioner Tisch that the local precincts cannot handle this; we need a special task force.‚Äù

The NYPD did not return Post requests for comment.

Councilwoman Vickie Paladino, a member of Holden‚Äôs Common-Sense Caucus, said a new law is needed to prevent illegal car stereos from hitting the streets.

‚ÄúWe proposed to make it illegal to operate a vehicle in New York State with a non-factory sound system installed which utilizes an external power supply,‚Äù Paladino said. ‚ÄúThis would make these cars impossible to register and inspect and subject them to impoundment if found in use.‚Äù

Residents and officials hope that the NYPD‚Äôs new Quality of Life Division, which launched Labor Day weekend, will help muffle the noise-causing car-speaker showdowns.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to see the Quality of Life units roll out in Queens and The Bronx first to address illegal parties,‚Äù Cane said. ‚ÄúRight now, it‚Äôs a constant headache.‚Äù
item.author: Matt Caputo
